data.text: Contents
Introduction

Urinary tract infection and chorioamnionitis are common infections associated with septic shock in the pregnant patient. The aim of these guidelines is to optimise treatment of women with suspected and confirmed urinary tract infection to reduce morbidity and mortality of mother and baby.
Incidence
Asymptomatic bacteriuria affects 2% to 10% of pregnant women, of whom up to 75% will develop symptomatic UTI and 30% acute pyelonephritis if untreated in pregnancy.
Cystitis complicates approximately 1% of pregnancies
Acute pyelonephritis complicates 1% of pregnancies. It is more common in pregnancy due to the physiological dilation of the upper renal tract.

Microscopic haematuria, in the absence of proteinuria, renal impairment or infection, is not uncommon in pregnancy and may relate to the bleeding from small venules in dilated collecting systems. If renal ultrasound (US) is normal no further investigation is required unless the haematuria persists postpartum.
Roles and responsibilities

The Specialist Nurse for Guidelines and Audit is responsible for ensuring clinical policies, guidelines and SOPs, are evidence-based and developed in line with national guidelines and following appropriate consultation.
The clinical director is responsible for the implementation of this guideline within the directorate.
The Head of Midwifery, maternity matrons and maternity managers are responsible for ensuring maternity staff are aware of the guideline and implement it.
The Obstetric Clinical Lead Consultant and Labour Ward Lead Consultant are responsible for ensuring the implementation of this guideline within the clinical setting.
All maternity staff are responsible for ensuring they are familiar with this guideline in relation to their practice and have the appropriate skills to implement this guideline.
What can go wrong?
Women who have history of previous UTI and are found to have bacteriuria, have a 10 fold increased risk of developing cystitis or acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy and adverse pregnancy outcome.
Pregnant women with lower urinary tract infections are at increased risk of pyelonephritis, resulting in preterm delivery and low fetal birth weight.
Antibiotic treatment taken for at least seven days reduces these risks.
Offer an immediate antibiotic prescription (see the recommendations on choice of antibiotic Microguide) to pregnant women with lower UTI. Take account of:
previous urine culture and susceptibility results
previous antibiotic use, which may have led to resistant bacteria
MicroGuide can be found with the following link : https://viewer.microguide.global/meht/adult#content,31a0ee05-db94-45f0-a662- bb9e4f187a6d
Obtain  a  midstream  urine  sample  from  pregnant  women  before  antibiotics  are taken, and send for culture and susceptibility testing.
For pregnant women with lower UTI:
review the choice of antibiotic when microbiological results are available, and
Change the antibiotic according to susceptibility results if the bacteria are resistant, using a narrow-spectrum antibiotic wherever possible.
Asymptomatic bacteriuria
Pathogenesis
75% - 90% of bacteriuria in pregnancy is because Escherichia-coli probably derived from the large bowel.
Colonisation of the urinary tract results from ascending infection from the perineum and may be related to sexual intercourse.
Diagnosis of Asymptomatic Bacteriuria
5.2.1 Most women with asymptomatic bacteriuria are infected during early pregnancy; very few subsequently acquire asymptomatic bacteriuria.
5.2.2 Bacteriuria is only considered significant if the colony count exceeds 100,000/mL on a mid-stream urine (MSU) specimen.
5.2.3 Urine cultures resulting in a non-significant or mixed growth should be repeated on a fresh MSU specimen.
5.2.4 Dipsticks for nitrites and leucocytes esterase may be used to help exclude UTI.
Management of Asymptomatic Bacteriuria
5.3.1 Because the dilation of the upper renal tract during pregnancy increases the risk of pyelonephritis, asymptomatic bacteriuria should be treated.
5.3.2 Treating asymptomatic bacteriuria reduces the risk of preterm delivery and low birth weight babies.
5.3.3 The choice of antibiotics depends on the sensitivities of the causative organism. Treat empirically as per Microguide until culture sensitivities are available.

5.3.4 A mid-stream specimen of urine must be taken regularly at follow-up antenatal appointments following treatment to ensure eradication of the organism. Approximately 15% of women will have recurrent bacteriuria during their pregnancy and require a second course of antibiotics.
Acute cystitis
Cystitis complicates approximately 1% to 3% of pregnancies.

6.1.2 UTI in pregnancy is more common with diabetic (both pre-existing and gestational), in those receiving systemic corticosteroids or other immunosuppressant drugs and in those with a history of previous recurrent UTI's (with or without structural renal abnormalities).
6.1.3 77% of infections are due to E-coli.
Diagnosis of acute cystitis
6.2.1 This is confirmed by finding of significant bacteriuria following cultures of an MSU specimen.
6.2.2 Microscopy of urine may reveal organisms, white cells and occasionally red cells, but the false positive rate is very high and it is no longer recommended for diagnosis of UTI.
6.2.3 The presence of nitrites and leukocytes is suggestive but not diagnostic of UTI.
Management of acute cystitis
6.3.1 The management of acute cystitis must be treated the same as asymptomatic bacteriuria.(Refer to point6.3)
6.3.2 Antibiotic therapy is guided by sensitivities of the organism.
6.3.3 Antibiotics must be continued for 7 days.
6.3.4 Several non-pharmacological manoeuvres may help to prevent recurrent infection in those women troubled by UTIs in pregnancy.
6.3.5 These include the following
Increasing fluid intake, this ensures frequent voiding and a high- volume, dilute urine, all of which reduce the risk of symptomatic infection.

Emptying the bladder following sexual intercourse. This ‘washes away' organisms massaged up the urethra from the perineum into the bladder during coitus, before they have a chance to replicate in urine within the bladder.
Double voiding ( to ensure no residual urine is left in the bladder following micturition)
The perineum must be cleaned from ‘front to back' following defecation to minimise the risk of bowel organisms colonizing the urethra.
Acute pyelonephritis  ( This complicates 1% to 2% of pregnancies)
Clinical Features of Acute Pyelonephritis
7.1.1 These include fever, loin and/or abdominal pain, vomiting, rigors, as well as proteinuria, haematuria and concomitant features of cystitis.
7.1.2 It is more common in women with diabetes, those on steroid and other immunosuppressant therapy and those with previous recurrent UTI's.
7.1.3 Other risk factors include the following:
Polycystic kidneys
Congenital abnormalities of the renal tract (duplex kidney or ureter, reflux nephropathy)
Neuropathic bladder (e.g. in those with spina bifida or multiple sclerosis)
Urinary tract calculi.
Diagnosis of Acute Pyelonephritis
(Refer to the guideline entitled ‘Management of pyrexia in the pregnancy and the intrapartum period'; register number 12032)
7.2.1 This is confirmed by the finding of significant bacteriuria following cultures of an MSU specimen.
7.2.2 Investigation in women with fever should include blood cultures, FBC, urea, electrolytes, liver function test, and CRP.
7.2.3 An MSU should be sent for culture and sensitivity.
Pregnancy Risks of Acute Pyelonephritis
7.3.1  Risk of preterm labour associated with pyrexia and increased risk of low birth weight babies.
Management of Acute Pyelonephritis
(Refer to the guideline entitled ‘Administration of antibiotics in Maternity' 3.0 (9043)
7.4.1 Hospital admission.
7.4.2 Once a diagnosis is suspected, I.V. antibiotics as per Microguide must begin immediately before awaiting MSU results.
7.4.3 In cases of septicemia or resistant organisms or women who are allergic to both penicillin's and cephalosporin's refer to Microguide but please always discuss with microbiologist.

7.4.4 There is theoretical risk of fetal ototoxicity with the use of gentamicin in pregnancy but provided drug levels are measured and kept within therapeutic range, this should not be a problem encountered in clinical practice.
7.4.5 Antibiotics must be given intravenously for at least 24 hours, when they may be changed to the appropriate oral formulation. Antibiotics must be continued for a period of at least 2 weeks.
7.4.6 Renal function must be checked every  hours, if there is associated sepsis.
7.4.7 Give Intravenous fluids if a woman's volume is depleted by inadequate intake, vomiting or sweating.
7.4.8 An ultrasound of the kidneys should be done to exclude hydronephrosis, congenital abnormalities and renal calculi.
Prophylaxis
7.5.1 Women who usually take antibiotic prophylaxis against UTI's should continue this in pregnancy.

7.5.2 Choice of antimicrobial will depend on the sensitivities of the usual infecting organisms. The prophylactic agent may need to be changed in pregnancy if there is intervening infection with resistant organism.
7.5.3 Two or more confirmed and documented UTIs in pregnancy renal ultrasound should be performed and antibiotic prophylaxis considered.
Urinary tract infection – points to remember
Escherichia coli is the most common organism responsible for causing UTI in pregnancy

If pain is the predominant symptom or subsequent culture reveals an atypical bacteria such as Proteus or Klebsiella species then consider the presence of urinary tract calculi. The first line investigation in this scenario is an ultrasound scan of the urinary tract.
Encourage pregnant women to re-attend if initial treatment is not successful.
Treatment of patients with asymptomatic bacteriuria (a positive culture without symptoms) is controversial as these women may be managed differently.

An issue relevant to primary care is group B streptococcal infection in pregnancy, which is associated with chorioamnionitis and neonatal disease. Women with group B streptococcal bacteriuria should receive a treatment course of antibiotics for seven days at the time of diagnosis and intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis consisting of a loading dose of benzylpenicillin followed by four-hourly doses for the duration of labour.
UTI is more common in pregnancy
Asymptomatic bacteriuria should be treated because there is a significant risk of acute pyelonephritis.
Acute pyelonephritis increases the risk of preterm labour.
Acute pyelonephritis should be managed in hospital with I.V. antibiotics.

Once antibiotic treatment has rendered the urine sterile, regular MSU specimens are necessary to exclude reinfection. A repeat specimen must be tested 7 days after the completion of the course of antibiotics.
Refer to Microguide for empiric antimicrobial recommendations. https://viewer.microguide.global/meht/adult#content,31a0ee05-db94-45f0-a662- bb9e4f187a6d
Investigations in cases of pyrexia and suspected acute pyelonephritis should include blood cultures, full blood count, renal function and renal US.
Staffing and training
All midwifery and obstetric staff must attend yearly mandatory training which includes skills and drills training.
All midwifery and obstetric staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are up-to-date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
Professional midwifery advocates

Professional Midwifery Advocates provide a mechanism of support and guidance to women and midwives. Professional Midwifery Advocates are experienced practising midwives who have undertaken further education in order to supervise midwifery services and to advise and support midwives and women in their care choices.
Infection prevention
All staff must follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.

All staff must ensure that they follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention. All invasive devices must be inserted and cared for using High Impact Intervention guidelines to reduce the risk of infection and deliver safe care. This care must be recorded in the Saving Lives High Impact Intervention Monitoring Tool Paperwork (Medical Devices).
Audit and monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy (register number 08076), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Maternity annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary Risk Management Group (MRMG) and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance
Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Patient Safety Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved locally by the Maternity and Gynaecology Practice Steering Group prior to submission to the Controlled Document team for ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

It is the Guidelines and Audit Nurse's and author's responsibility to inform the Maternity and Gynaecology Practice Steering Group and appropriate Maternity Services' staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
This Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to appendix B)
References
Foxman B. (2014) Urinary tract infection syndromes: occurrence, recurrence, bacteriology, risk factors, and disease burden. Infectious Disease Clinics of North America 28(1):1-13.

Smaill FM, Vazquez JC. Antibiotics for asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews , Issue . Art. No.: CD000490. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD000490.pub3. Available at: www.cochranelibrary.com/cdsr/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD000490.pub4/full

Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (2012) Management of suspected bacterial urinary tract infection in adults (SIGN 88). Edinburgh: Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network. Available at: www.sign.ac.uk/our- guidelines/management-of-suspected-bacterial-urinary-tract-infection-in-adults/

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence, (2020). Health Topics A-Z. When should I suspect lower urinary tract infection? Available at: https://cks.nice.org.uk/topics/urinary-tract-infection-lower-women/diagnosis/when-to- suspect-uti/
BMJ Practice. 10 minute consultation. A likely urinary tract uinfectio in a pregnant woman. BMJ 2017; 357; j177. Available at:
https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.j1777
